reasoning: The critique targets the position’s “strongest-link” counterargument (that at least one compute-light route will avoid bottlenecks), which is a meaningful but not fully load-bearing pillar among several independent reasons given for high substitutability/late compute binding; hence moderate centrality. It offers a plausible unifying objection—many purported escape routes still require substantial compute for training/inference and, especially, high-trust validation—so it does weaken that specific pivot. However, it is somewhat schematic (asserts convergence to a compute-gated validation regime without tightly arguing that small-scale extrapolation, algorithmic efficiency gains, or other non-P4 considerations can’t deliver early-stage acceleration), so it doesn’t strongly undermine the overall thesis. Most claims are broadly accurate/plausible, though not demonstrated and somewhat overstated in places. The critique is clear, focused, and has little extraneous material.
title: All escape routes still require frontier-scale compute for trustworthy validation
